description: Coherent errors are deterministic, unitary deviations from the intended gate operation. Unlike stochastic Pauli errors, coherent errors are systematic and can accumulate constructively, potentially causing error rates that scale quadratically with circuit depth rather than linearly.
Common examples include over-rotation (applying Rz(θ + δ) instead of Rz(θ)), axis tilts (rotating about a slightly wrong axis), and phase errors from frequency miscalibration.

Coherent errors are particularly insidious because they can evade detection by methods designed for stochastic errors. However, they can be converted to stochastic errors through randomized compiling (Pauli twirling).

properties.Parameters: Depends on error type (rotation angle error, axis tilt, etc.)
properties.Reversibility: Fully reversible if error is known
properties.Accumulation: Can add constructively: error grows as O(n) or O(n²) with circuit depth n

qem_considerations: Pauli twirling converts coherent errors to stochastic (incoherent) errors
Dynamical decoupling can cancel low-frequency coherent errors
Echo verification exploits time-reversal to detect coherent errors
ZNE may not work directly (coherent errors may not scale linearly with folding)
Noise-aware compilation can minimize exposure to known coherent error sources
